discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
B answer in incorrect
As per Cisco book
"The active unit keeps CAPWAP tunnels,
AP states, client states, configurations, and image files all in sync with the hot standby unit.
If the active unit fails, the hot standby unit quickly takes over the active role"

Selected Answer: D
Only clients that are in Run state are synced between the Active and Standby WLC. Client SSO does not support seamless transitions for clients that are in the process of associating/joining the controller. The clients in the transition phase will be de-authenticated after switchover and will need to rejoin the controller.

no deatails about the WLC status in public spaces. in that case we assume that there is no issue with the connetivity between WLCs
Round trip latency on Redundancy Link should be less than or equal to 80 milliseconds.
Preferred MTU on Redundancy Link is 1500 or above.
Bandwidth on Redundancy Link should be 60 Mbps or more.

Selected Answer: D
This is tough - both B and D are valid answers here (typical Cisco SMH).... but I think the key word is "public", which tells me a lot of clients might be in the "WebAuth_Req" state because it's a public space and clients have to authenticate first and Cisco is likely looking for D as the answer.

Selected Answer: D
I'd say the correct answer is D afterall. I do not like B, because in the SSO, the syncing should be transactional - I cannot imagine you can sync half of the database.

Selected Answer: D
Official Cert Guide page 201:
The active controller also synchronizes the state of each associated client that is in the RUN state with the hot standby controller.

Any client which is not associated or in the RUN state will not show.

Selected Answer: B
I would vote for B. 
I can't accept if D is correct. Realistically, there would be only few clients (or mostly zero) which are in an interim state such as "WebAuth_Req". Since the question is mentioning half, then lack of a fully replicated database is more probable.

A and C can't be right anyway.

questions.question_text: WLC SSO is set up between two WLCs in a service provider network serving public spaces. On WLC failover, it is noticed that only about half of the original client count is now showing on the secondary WLC, although it is currently showing the role as active. Which design side case explains the issue?

choices.D: Some client sessions were in WebAuth-Req state before failover.
choices.A: The secondary WLC platform does not support the required client count.
choices.B: The WLCs had not completed database sync before the primary failure.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A- even the RP is down. RMI can be UP, so the peer connectivity will be checked over network infrastructure . in that time Standy will go to maintainance mode
B - still RP is active and peer can be seem .
C- this will cause switches to have split brain cause WLC to do the same since RP, RMI all are down.
its a LAG , so two or more can be aggregated . here one port down wont disconnect any connectivities.

Selected Answer: C
C should be right.

According to: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/technotes/8-7/High_Availability_DG.html 'network issues' diagramm

A: Standby will reboot
B: no action
D: no action

When VSL gets cut, switches might go into split brain, which cuts RP Link aswell as some connectivity of wlcs so they might also go into split brain.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/wireless/ha-failover-when-rp-disconnected/td-p/3919644 Last comment with juniper firewalls

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A WLC SSO pair is set up. Which failure scenario causes a split-brain scenario?

choices.D: One distribution port on the active WLC is down.
choices.B: Two distribution ports on the active WLC are down.

questions.question_text: A customer is deploying an 802.11ac network on a floor to support approximately 300 wireless devices. Which setting must be changed on Cisco Prime Infrastructure Planning Tool to predict the number of APs the customer needs to service the new floor?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
When deploying an 802.11ac wireless network to support a specific number of devices (300 wireless clients), the Cisco Prime Infrastructure Planning Tool must account for device density and bandwidth demand.

Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer is D

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/net_mgmt/prime/network_control_system/1-2/user/guide/prime_ncs_ug/create_maps.html

Thick wall - 13 dB
Light wall - 2 dB
Heavy door - 15 dB
Light door - 4 dB
Glass - 1.5 dB

Do you think the correct would be that obvious?

Selected Answer: D
D is the right one as @networkJoe provided the info

questions.question_text: When a wireless survey is conducted at a customer facility, signal attenuation in an area that is surrounded by thick glass walls is noted as 2dB. When Cisco Prime Infrastructure is configured, which obstacle must be placed in a map editor to represent the impact that the glass wall will have on the RF signal in the facility?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Mine shafts are long narrow corridors, you would get more use out of a patch antenna as you don't require signal in all directions and the gain increase to reach further down the shaft.

questions.question_text: An engineer must perform a Layer 2 survey for a mining facility. Which type of antenna does the engineer use in the mine shaft?
